title: When filing a writ of execution with the court do I need to do a affidavit supporting the writ?
question: Will there be a hearing for it also?
answers:
The writ of execution is the form that the court uses to tell the sheriff or other levying officer that the plaintiff has an unsatisfied judgment against the plaintiff.

The court issues the writ if it has an unsatisfied judgment on file. Because it is the best judge of its files contents, you do not need an affidavit.

CCP section 699.510 governs the issuance of writs of execution. http://www.leginfo.ca.gov/cgi-bin/displaycode?section=ccp&group=00001-01000&file=699.510-699.560

CCP sections 685.010, et seq., govern the computation of interest. http://www.leginfo.ca.gov/cgi-bin/displaycode?section=ccp&group=00001-01000&file=685.010-685.110

If the matter is an unlimited civil matter, you will need to submit along with the writ a declaration of interest. Some county court websites provide their own form.

Last, if you want judgment enforcement costs to be added to the judgment (and the writ) -- for any type of civil matter (small claims, limited or unlimited) -- you will need to submit with the writ a post-judgment Memo of Costs: http://www.courts.ca.gov/documents/mc012.pdf.
